messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 53 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Speeding Up the NSGA-II With a Simple Tie-Breaking Rule

Paper Abstract: Abstract The non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm II (NSGA/ÃÑII) is the most popular multi-objective optimization heuristic. Recent mathematical runtime analyses have detected two shortcomings in discrete search spaces, namely, that the NSGA-II has difficulties with more than two objectives and that it is very sensitive to the choice of the population size. To overcome these difficulties, we analyze a simple tie-breaking rule in the selection of the next population. Similar rules have been proposed before, but have found only little acceptance. We prove the effectiveness of our tie-breaking rule via mathematical runtime analyses on the classic OneMinMax, LeadingOnesTrailingZeros, and OneJumpZeroJump benchmarks. We prove that this modified NSGA-II can optimize the three benchmarks efficiently also for many objectives, in contrast to the exponential lower runtime bound previously shown for OneMinMax with three or more objectives. For the bi-objective problems, we show runtime guarantees that do not increase when moderately increasing the population size over the minimum admissible size. For example, for the OneJumpZeroJump problem with representation length nùëõn and gap parameter kùëòk, we show a runtime guarantee of O‚Äã(max‚Å°{nk+1,N‚Äãn})ùëÇsuperscriptùëõùëò1ùëÅùëõO(\max\{n^{k+1},Nn\}) function evaluations when the population size is at least four times the size of the Pareto front. For population sizes larger than the minimal choice N=Œò‚Äã(n)ùëÅŒòùëõN=\Theta(n), this result improves considerably over the Œò‚Äã(N‚Äãnk)ŒòùëÅsuperscriptùëõùëò\Theta(Nn^{k}) runtime of the classic NSGA/ÃÑII.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 53 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 53"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Theory of Randomized Search Heuristics",
        "SMS-EMOA: Multiobjective selection based on dominated hypervolume",
        "Better running time of the non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm II (NSGA-II) by using stochastic tournament selection",
        "A general approach to running time analysis of multi-objective evolutionary algorithms",
        "An archive can bring provable speed-ups in multi-objective evolutionary algorithms",
        "Stochastic population update can provably be helpful in multi-objective evolutionary algorithms",
        "Runtime analysis of quality diversity algorithms",
        "Analyzing hypervolume indicator based algorithms",
        "The first proven performance guarantees for the Non-Dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II) on a combinatorial optimization problem",
        "Evolutionary Algorithms for Solving Multi-Objective Problems",
        "Design and analysis of diversity-based parent selection schemes for speeding up evolutionary multi-objective optimisation",
        "Analysing the robustness of NSGA-II under noise",
        "A proof that using crossover can guarantee exponential speed-ups in evolutionary multi-objective optimisation",
        "An evolutionary many-objective optimization algorithm using reference-point-based nondominated sorting approach, part I: solving problems with box constraints",
        "A fast and elitist multiobjective genetic algorithm: NSGA-II",
        "Runtime analysis for state-of-the-art multi-objective evolutionary algorithms on the subset selection problem",
        "Speeding Up the NSGA-II With a Simple Tie-Breaking Rule (Code)",
        "Lower bounds for the runtime of a global multi-objective evolutionary algorithm",
        "Difficulties of the NSGA-II with the Many-Objective LeadingOnes Problem",
        "Multiplicative up-drift",
        "Optimizing linear functions with the (1+Œª)1ùúÜ(1+\\lambda) evolutionary algorithm‚Äîdifferent asymptotic runtimes for different instances",
        "Theory of Evolutionary Computation‚ÄîRecent Developments in Discrete Optimization",
        "A first runtime analysis of the NSGA-II on a multimodal problem",
        "From understanding the population dynamics of the NSGA-II to the first proven lower bounds",
        "Runtime analysis for the NSGA-II: Provable speed-ups from crossover",
        "Theoretical analyses of multi-objective evolutionary algorithms on multi-modal objectives",
        "On the analysis of the (1+1) evolutionary algorithm",
        "Revisiting the NSGA-II crowding-distance computation",
        "Expected runtimes of a simple multi-objective evolutionary algorithm",
        "On the effect of populations in evolutionary multi-objective optimisation",
        "A runtime analysis of typical decomposition approaches in MOEA/D framework for many-objective optimization problems",
        "Analyzing Evolutionary Algorithms ‚Äì The Computer Science Perspective",
        "On the choice of the offspring population size in evolutionary algorithms",
        "Running time analysis of multiobjective evolutionary algorithms on pseudo-Boolean functions",
        "Running time analysis of multi-objective evolutionary algorithms on a simple discrete optimization problem",
        "A primary theoretical study on decomposition-based multiobjective evolutionary algorithms",
        "Bioinspired Computation in Combinatorial Optimization ‚Äì Algorithms and Their Computational Complexity",
        "Population size matters: rigorous runtime results for maximizing the hypervolume indicator",
        "Runtime analyses of NSGA-III on many-objective problems",
        "A first running time analysis of the Strength Pareto Evolutionary Algorithm 2 (SPEA2)",
        "Maintaining diversity provably helps in evolutionary multimodal optimization",
        "Convergence Properties of Evolutionary Algorithms",
        "Convergence time analysis for the multi-objective counting ones problem",
        "A mathematical runtime analysis of the Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm III (NSGA-III)",
        "Near-tight runtime guarantees for many-objective evolutionary algorithms",
        "Runtime analysis of the (Œºùúá\\mu + 1) EA on simple pseudo-Boolean functions",
        "Mathematical runtime analysis for the non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm II (NSGA-II)",
        "Approximation guarantees for the Non-Dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II)",
        "Runtime analysis for the NSGA-II: proving, quantifying, and explaining the inefficiency for many objectives",
        "Runtime analysis of the SMS-EMOA for many-objective optimization",
        "A first mathematical runtime analysis of the Non-Dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II)",
        "Multiobjective evolutionary algorithms: A survey of the state of the art",
        "Evolutionary Learning: Advances in Theories and Algorithms"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 53 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Speeding Up the NSGA-II With a Simple Tie-Breaking Rule, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
